head.title: Australians Know How to Handle Sun

hedline.hl1: Australians Know How to Handle Sun

block.p: After seeing a news report highlighting advice from the weather services now being disseminated to the American public about ultraviolet radiation factors for the following day, I was surprised that it has taken America this long to educate itself about the risks of sun exposure.

After seeing a news report highlighting advice from the weather services now being disseminated to the American public about ultraviolet radiation factors for the following day, I was surprised that it has taken America this long to educate itself about the risks of sun exposure.

Among the precautions that people are being advised to take are wearing loose, light-colored clothing, drinking plenty of liquids, preferably water, as opposed to alcoholic or sweetened or caffeinated beverages, wearing a large-brimmed hat to protect the face and wearing coated sunglasses to protect the eyes.

Take it from a country that does not benefit from a sheltering smog and has little or no ozone layer left. Always wear a sunscreen with a sun protection factor of at least 15 (you'll still get a tan) and don't go out into the sun between 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. Don't bother listening to your weather reporter. STEPHANIE PRATT Canberra, Australia, July 4, 1994
